div.l: For sikerly whan I was born a noon
Deeth drough the tappe of lyfe and leet it goon
And eủer sithe hath soo the tap y ronne
Til that almost empti is the tonne
The streem of lyfe now droppeth on the chymbe
The sely tonge may wele rynge and chymbe
Of wrecchednesse that is passed full yore
With olde folke saue dotage is namore
bHe gan to speke as lordly as a kyngeTransposition of 45-46 corrected by "ba" marks in the margin.
aWhan that oure hoost had herde this sermonynge
He seide what amounteth all this witte
What shall we speke alday of holy writte
The deuel made a Reue for to preche
Or of a souter / a shipman / or a leche
Sey forth thy tale / and tarie nought the tyme
Lo depeford / and it is half wey prime
Lo Grenewiche / ther many a shrewe is ynne
It were al tyme thi tale to be gynne
Now seres quod this Oswold the Reue
I pray yow alle that ye // yow // noughtyow noughtnought yow greue
Thow I answere / and somdele sette his howue
For leueful it is with force / force of showue
This dronken Millere hath I tolde vs here
How that bygyled was a Carpentere
ꝐParauenture in scorne for I am oon
And by youre leue I shall hym quyte a noon
Right in his cherles termes wole I speke
I pray to god his nekke mote breke
He kan wele in myn ye seen a stalklestallestalke
But in his owen / he kan not sen a balke
At Trompyngton nat fer fro Cantebrigge
Ther gooth a broke and oủer that a brigge Narrat
Vpon the whiche brook ther stant a MeilleMilleMelle
And this is verray soth that I yow telle
A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
As any peocokpocokpecok / he was prout and gay
Pipen he koude / and fisshe and nettes bete
And tourne coppes / and wele wrastle and shete
And by his belte he bare a longe panade
Made of a swerde / full trenchaunt was the blade
